div.head:
FINANCIAL CRISIS.
FURTHER FALL IN CONSOLS.

div.p: The "Times," in a leading article, deprecates the action of the political agitators in raising the cry of an extraordinary and portentous decline in prices. It anticipates a healthier condition with the regular purchase of Consols for the sinking fund, provided that new securities are not created. (Reuter)
Consoh fell to 84 J A general liquidation is proceeding in all the stock markets The Continental markets are overloaded and there is heavy pressure to sell. {Reuter)
The natives have assassinated the French doctor Mauchamp, director of the dispensary at Maraketch. The members of the Diplomatic Corps have expressed indignation at this crime.
( Havas)
The French doctor Mauchamp has been shot and then stoned to death in a street in Marrakesh..
The cruiser Jeanne d'Arc has been ordered to Morocco. It is believed that France will demand heavy compensation. (Reuter)

The murder of Dr. Mauchamp was due to his having erected a flagstaff for geodetic purposes which the natives believed to be part of a wireless installation. The British Consulate was stoned but no one was hurt. Moorish guards have been provided. (Reuter)
Mohamed Torres has apologised for the assassination of the French doctor at Maraketch. (Havas)

A considerable sensation has been caused in the Duma by the fact that the Government has heartily accepted the proposal of the Constitutional Democrats to appoint a commission to supervise famine relief. The co-operation of this group with the Government is regarded as of hopeful augury. (Reuter)

div.head:
WAR IN HONDURAS
WARNING FROM U.S.A.

div.p: Mr Root received the Nicaraguan and Costa-Rican Ministers and impressed upon them the necessity for ending the war in Honoras, otherwise all Central America will be- ome involved and European intervention will robably result (Reuter)

div.head:
CHINESE IN S AFRICA.
GOVERNMENT POLICY.

div.p: Prior to the adjournment of the Assembly the Progressives urged the Government to appoint a commission of enquiry on the Chinese question. Mr. Smuts refused and declared that the Government would faithfully fulfil its pledge to solve the labour question. (Reuter)
The Government has called out 30,000 «serves to deal with the peasant revolt. (R ) Bckareht, March 24
The agrarian disorders have led to the resig at ion of the Conservative Cabinet. A Liberal- [ inis try has been formed. (Reuter)

div.head: Italy and Abbysinia. Treaty of Commerce

div.p: The Senate has given its approval to the treaty of commerce with Ethiopia.
The House of Commons has rejected the Metric System Bill introduced by Mr. Strauss (Reuter
The Franco-Siamese treaty has been signed. France obtains the provinces of Angkor, Bat- tambang, and Sisophon. (Havas
In consequence of a warlike speech General Picquart has taken the place of General Bail- lod, who will take the Montpellier command. (Havas)

Mr. Birrell in the H'*use of Commons yesterday disclosed the impending Irish legislation recently mentioned. An annual grant of £40,000 is to be made for 3 years for the purpose of school building, and also to encourage the teaching of the Irish language. The administrât on of education will be in the hands of the Irish themselves. (Reuter
M. Pobédonostzew, ex-Procurator of the Holy Synod, is dead. (Reuter)

div.head: THE LATE M Br R1 HELOT

div.p: Parliament has authorised the burial of Mr. and Mrs. Berthelot in the Pantheon. (Havas)

div.head: Arablo Instruction.
div.p: ' A1 Garida " states that the Ministry of PnbHc In miction intends to teach geography in the Primary schools in the Arabic Ian- guage.

div.head: Egyptian Institute.
div.p: The usual Monthly meeting of the Egyprian Institute has been postponed until the 8th proxo as the first Monday in April is Easter Monday.

div.head: Coptic Teachers.
div.p: A number of Coptic teachers lett Cairo for Suez on Thursday on their way to Abyssinia. They have been ordered by the Coptic Patriarch to teach in the schools of Abysrinia.

div.head: Press and Municipality.
div.p: Alexandria correspondents of the Cairo Press have addressed « protest to the Ministry of the Interior against the decision of the Alexandria Municipal Commission not to allow the Cairo Newspapers to be represented at its meetings.

div.head: Smallpox Epldemlo.
div.p: We would draw the attention of our reader- to an important notice of the M nicipality which appears in another column of to-day's issue regarding the necessity of vaccination against smallpox, which is spreading to an alarming extent. 133 fresh cases have been registered since ''arch 1.

div.head: Moslem Female Emancipation.
div.p: " Al Minbar " in an artie'e the social position of Women in Islam, trys to prove the disadvantages or rather the evils of the European custom of the eraancipa iou of women. It, " Al Minbar, " says ruins the home life and plays skittles with family-ties and relations. It was the cause of many incurable social, mental, and bodily diseases which are still the ourses and abuses of modern civilisation.

div.head: EGYPITAN NATIONALISM. THE KHEDIVE'S POSITION. INTERESTING DECLARATION.
div.p: The Khedive interviewed by the correspondent of the "Temps" denied that the aim of the Nationalists in Egypt was an'i-foreign or fanatical. His Highness said that he had learned in Europe the necessity for the Sovereign to be iu accord with his people. ( Reuter) LONDON, March 22.

HOUSE OP COMMONS.—Mr. Lonsdale asked the Government to impress on the Khedive's Government the necessity of dealing drastically with nationalist agitation. Sir E. Grey said he must repeat his answer given to other requests to intervene in Egypt in matters wherein the Government had full confidence in the discretion of Lord Cromer. He did not propose to send any special instructions. (Reuter)
LONDON. March 23

Sir C. Furness, Member of Parliament, in a. letter to the "Times," expresses regret at the lack of wisdom displayed by Mr. John Robertson in attacking the British Administration in Egypt and especially in abusing Lord Cromer in a native revolutionary newspaper. (Reuter)
The Paris correspondent of Mustapha Pasha Kamel has telegraphed the following news, which is reproduced from his newspaper :— Paris, 23 March.
The Temps publishes to-day important declarations made by his Highness the Khedive to its special represeutative in Egypt
The Khedive says : "I love my country passiouately as every Egyptian knows how to love it. We are devoted to this laud ; it is our own, our good, our love. We could not endure death far away from it.
The Egyptian people is a progressive people. The Khedive says he is astonished at the prodigious facility with which the Egyptians assimilate European c-dture.
He s iys that "it is time to make every possible effort for the satisfaction of the intellectual and moral needs of the Egyptian people."

The Khedive denies categorically the existence of any fanaticism iu Egypt and says : "The Egyptian people are good by nature, honest, laborious and tolerant Tolerance is one of the great laws of our religion.

The Khedive next si^eaks of the accusation urged against him of wishing to establinh his personal power in order to exercise it in the Oriental fasion He replies to this accusation hy saying that he Jias learned and understood by his Eur pean education "the necessity for the co-operation of the Ration with the Sovereign for the administration and benefit of the country.
The Khedive says :
"Despotic government would be too heavy a task for my shoulders."
He ends by saying :
"I have worked with all my strength for the good of the co -ntry. I have never offered opposition to the measures I believed to be useful for Egypt. I have never refused to listen to advice."

div.head: CAIRO ESTATES COMPANY
div.p: We publish in another part of our paper today the prospectus of the above company. It is hardly necessary considering the favourable a'-spices under which it is issued for us to recommend it to our readers or investors generally. The unprecedented success ot the Egyptian Estates under the able management pLMr. Montagu Summers has deservedly won tke confidence of the Egyptian public both European and native. The result of this has been to place the Egyptian Estates Company in a position to do more business of a throughly sound nature than its funds will permit, and sooner than refuse altogether the many investments offered, it has been decided to create an affiliated company under the above name. This company is an Egypt:an one and on that account will save the expense of a London Board, the Fnglish inoome tax, stamp duties, etc., and will be managed by the Egyptian Estates for a nominal fee whereby the shareholders will receive the fullest benefit of the profits in dividends. It is intended to give a preferent al allotment to the shareholders of the Egyptian Estates, which will work out to about one share for every twelve shares held in the latter company. There is DO whatever that the capital offered will be largely over subscribed and that the shares which are offered for subscription at the par value will soon attain a high premium.
The shares are all one class, there being neither Deferred, Founders, or Preference shares.

div.head: THE GRANDMOULIN AFFAIR
div.p: "Al Watan" says :—

The "Liwa, ' because of its hatred to all Europeans, considers that M. Grandmoulin is an assassin and that Mr. Moore is a concessionaire becai se one of his enemies alleged so. Aft-r thus passing judgment, that pape asks France for Grandmoulin's life and calls for the lifelong incarceration of Mr. Moore in prison.

Leaving aside the responsibility which a newspaper incurs by bringing such premat re accusations, such tactics as these are an illegal and odious form of meddling with the cour-e of justice as the judges may be in some degree influenced thereby. The Govern ment onght to take proceedings in such a case against all those who attempt to influence judges by taking a side. To pronounce an opinion on a matter pendents lite is a crime which no journalists ought tb he gnilty of in civilised countries.

div.head: H.M.S BEDFORD
div.p: Collision in Red Sea
(PROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
8 ez, 24th March.

H.M S. "Bedford" came out of the Canal yesterday morning and proceeded in the Red Sea, but while passing the New Port rock lighthouse, she collided with the British S.^. "Ca^tello," which waa at the time coming up from the Red Sea. The collision appears to be a serious one. and the "Castello" was badly damaged in the bows and is now moored in the Port Ibrahim Basin at Suez in order to be surveyed.
'1 he cr >iser however, appears to be undamaged, as after the collision she proceeded at once without stopping.

div.head: NILE FLOTILLA COMPANY, L.T.D
div.p: The Nile Flotilla Company Limited has acoept**d the offer of the Express Nile Steamers Company for the purchase of its fleet, lease, good-will, etc. The fleet that is being handed over consists of two tugs and eleven barges. The price is L.E. 14,000. in cash and LE. 8,000 in shares of the Express Nile Company. Tho offer was made and accepted on Thursday last.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN INVESTMENT AND AGENCY LIMITED.
div.p: Monsieur le Directeur, de T "Egyptian Gazette."

Monsieur,— Nous vous prions de joindre notre protestation à celles des autres actionnaires de The Egyptian Investment and Agency Limited contre le Conseil d'Adminis- trati n de cette Société, au sujet de l'immobilisation dans les caisses de The Anv'lo-Egyptian Bank Limited, de 15 schelling non encore appelés.
Recevez, Monsieur, nos salutations dinting- uées.
MOÏSE TILCHE FILS.
Alexandrie, 28 Mars.

div.head:
EXPRESS NILE CO.
REMARKABLE MANOEUVRES.
div.p: The greatest interest prevails in Cairo owing to the "Squeeze" in Express Nile old shares. It is rumoured that 9,600 shares have been sold and there are only 7,500 in existence. This morning the shares are said to have touched £45 They closed from £35 to £40 no sellers It is believed that only two or three brokers are concerned and the general public remains uninfluenced.

div.head: THE SUDAN LAND AND COMMERCIAL COMPANY.
div.p: The capital of this Company is £250,000, in 50,000 shares of £5 each, which have been entirely subscribed as follows : Messrs. George Zervudachi, 6,000, Michel Sinadino, 6,000, Emanuel Stross, 6,000, A. Swinglehurst, 1,000, Demosthenes Tambacopoulo, 6,000, A. Capato, 12,500, B. Stamatopoulo, 12,500.
The board of directors consists of Messrs. George Zervudachi, Michel Sinadino, Emanuel Stross, H. Swinglehurst, Demosthenes Tampacopoulo, Angelo Capato, and Basile Stamatopoulo.
The objects of the Company are thus described in the Statutes :

La Soci té a pour objet l'achat et la vente de tous biens immobiliers, la construction sur terrains urbains d'immeubles de rapport, la mise en valeur et l'exploitation par tous les moyons des biens ruraux, les entreprises et travaux pour son propre compte ou pour compte des tiers, les prêts hypothécaires et le commerce d'importation et d'exportation au Soudan Anglo-Egypien principalement.

div.head: LA BRASSERIE RT RIZERIE D'ALEXANDRIE (BOMONTE).
div.p: This new company has completed the construction of its brewery on the Mahmondieb Canal at Alexandria. The ground occupied is four fe Idang in extent and the new building is provided with all the latest brewing improve. ments known. The tanks have been imported directly from the United States and the rest of the apparatus is from the Continent The actual work of brewing will begin in a month's time. The building and chimney are constructod of sand-bricks made by the Arenolite Company of Alexandria. These Arenolite sand-bricks have been found to be most practical as they allow the structure to be erected with much lightness owing to their great cohesive charaoter. They also proved to be a very cheap material för building purposes in comparison with the ordinary local builders' stock-in-trade of the same type. The building is an imposing construction, five stories high, and the design is excellently adapted to the style. The beer brewed will be Pilsner and the capacity of the brewery is about thirty thousand hecto| litres per annum.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. "Egyptian Prince," with passengers and general cargo, left Malta on the 22nd inst. and is due at Alexandria to-morrow,
The Ellerman liner ndalusian arrived this morning from Liverpool, Gibraltar, Malta, and Migratą (Barbary) with a general cargo
The Messageries Maritimes S. S. "Niger" which is due here to-morrow, lett Marseilles on the 21st inst. and passed the Straits of Messina on Saturday at 9 a.m

div.head: ZAGAZIG RACES.
div.p: 3. A SUCCESSFUL MEETING.

We think that those people who were lucky nough to receive invitations for Friday's races t Zagazig, or wise enough to come on their wn, have good reason to congratulate themelves. Wirhout putting too great a strain on ur stock of adjectives we can only describe Friday's meeting as a gigantic and stupendous uccess. On arriving at the conrse it was at nce evident that no pains had been spared, -nd we may add no expense to ensure the omfort of vi-itors. Four enclosures, & paddock und two stands, a huge luncheon tent from which many preferred to watch the races to

void the crowd, soon put to rest any fears of possible discomfort that may have been enertained. While on the subject of luncheon ents we must not forget to give unstinted praise to the excellence of the lo cheon and the perfection of all the arrangements made by the Wagon-lits Co. all of which were under the he personal superintendance of Mr. Tite. The erowd was enormous and exceeded all expecta-ion. Every stand and enclosure • as full to overflowing and at a modest comp'itation nine or ten thousand persons must have witnessed he racing. L.E. 260 were taken at the gates and the receipts from all sources totalled just ander L.E. 400

The police arrangements reflected great credit on all concerned and the executive committee are to be congratulated on having brought to a successfull issue what may be Fightly described, as the biggest show ever attempted in the Provinces.

Much regret was expressed that the Adviser co the Interior was unable to attend with Lady Valda Machell and among other distinguished absentees who were compelled to decline at che last moment were Şir William Garstin and Mr. Michell Innes. Among those present we noticed Coles Pasha, the Mudirs of Sharqia, Daqalia and Behera. Mohamed Sharwarbi Pasha. Ibrahim Murad Pasha, Ismail Pasha Abbaza, Mouheb Pasha and Amin Shemsi Pasha, Ishak Bey Hussein, etc., etc. Of the visitors from Cairo we recognised Captain and : Mrs Gilson, Captain and Mrs Rome, Mrs. Bayley and Miss Schreiber, Sir James and Miss Blyth, Sir Robert Harvey, Mr. and Mrs. Hood, Mr. and Mrs. Stout, Mr. and Mrs. Schreiber, Mr. and Mrs. Morcom, Messrs. Carter Wilson, Langley, Williams, Marsham, MacMurdo, Aspinall, Moberley. de Freville and Miller, Miss de Freville, Col. Persse, etc. There were also present many other guests of the entertainment committee, which consisted of 12 of the notables of the Province,' with Mr. Wa ker Berla as secretary whi had issued invitations to all the principal officials in the d fferent ministries.

The thanks of the committee are especially due to Coles Pasha who kindly acted as judge, to Captain Grant as starter, Mr. Way the Hon. Sec. and Hafiz Bey Hassan and the other Moudirieh officials who assisted in different ways. The land for the course was generously lent by Hassan Bey Abou Hassein, Omdeh of Kafre Abou Resh.

A special train stopping at the course was provided for the colivenience of visitors from Cairo. The band and pipers of the K.O.S.B's by kind permission of Col. Macfarlane and the officers of the regiment played during the afternoon. The Zagazig town band and the boys from the Abou Kebir school, kindly lent by Aly Bey Shakir, were also in attendance.
A correspondent writes :
"The whole "show" from start to finish was voted an immense success by all those who were fortunate enough to be numbered among the many thousands of spectators present at Friday's Races at Zagazig."

"The result reflects thegreatest possible credit upon the energetic organizer of the meeting and upon the entertainment Committee in general. It will hardly be considered invidious to single out Captain Grant, the popular and energetic Inspector of Interior of the province, and Mr. Way, of the Agricultural Bank, to whose remarkable powers of organization and indefatigable efforts the success attained was largely due. It is much to be regretted that Cairenes did not avail themselves in larger numbers of the special train to Zagazig, and the absence of the advisers and many high officials was undoubtedly felt by the many Bedouin Sheikhs and native notables present. However, the glowing accounts of the day's doings brought back to Cairo doubtless by those fortunate enough to have been present, ! will surely bring to the next meeting many of those who were absent on this occasion. With regard to the racing it only is necessary to add that the race for the Visitors Cup. --& magnificent silver bowl presented by the members of entertainment Committee-resulted in a very popular win by Mr. R. Way on Hankow. This result was a fitting end to this gentleman's untiring labours to promote the success of the first racing meeting at Zagazig." The following are the results :

FIRST RACE, 2.30 p.m. Sharqia Stakes. Value P.T. 2,000 of which P.T. 300 to the 2nd and 200 to the 3rd. For horses the property of Bedouin Arabs of Sharqia Province, to be ridden in Arab dress by owner or one of his family, Distance 2 miles. Entrance P.T. 100.
1. Sheikh Salimon Mohammed Khadr'sch.a. h. Siah.
2. Saoud El-Tabawy's ch ach Ghazali 3. Amin Bey Badran's ga h. Makbul.
Fifteen started Farhan made the running at first, but before ha f the distance was passed Siah went to the front and won easily with Makbul a good third.

SECOND RACE, 8 p.m. Desert Scurry. Value P.T. 1,500 of which P.T. 300 to the 2nd and 200 to the 3rd. For Arab ponies the property of any landowner in SHarqia province. Confined to 4 year oids and der. Distance 1 2 mile. Entranoe P.T. 76. 1. Mansour Bey. Nasrallah's g.a m. Mallodia, 2. Abou Zeid's b.a h. Farah. 3. Sheikh Ahmed Badran's g a.h. Aloun. Eight starters. A good start but Mallodia on showed in front and thanks to his minutive jockey won in a canter by ten ngths.

THIRD RACE, 3.30 p.m The Tel El Kebir Stakes. Value P.T. 1,500 which P.T 300 to the second and 200 to ird. For Arab Horses the property of Bedouin rabs of Sharqia Province to be ridden in rab dress by owner or one of his family. istance 1 1/2 miles. Entrance P.T. 75. 1. Sheikh Kadam effendi El Tahawy's b.a.m.
eria.
2. Amin Bey Badran's b a.h. Nakhledi 3 Sheike Mobammed Migelli's g.a.h. Misish.
Sixteen starters. S FOUR IH RACE 5.30 p..

The Visitors Race for a Silver Cup pre. ented by the Members of the Municipality of agazig and a sweepstake of P.T. 100 to be ivided in the proportion of 3.2.1. Confined to arab hacks and morour ponies the property of British residents in Egypt, that have never een placed in any race under K.SC, A S.C. r Helouan Ş.C. Rules and which are not kept or racing purposes. Catch weights 11st 7 lbs. Iorse stabled regularly in the Provinces llowed 7 lbs. Distance one mile. The Stewards eserve the right to refuse any entry.
1. Mr. R. H, Way's, b,a.h. Hankowie. 2. Mr. M. Moberly's, g.a.h. Nisre. 3. Mr. T. Mullin's, g.a.b. Ibn el Nur.
Also ran Mr. H. M. Blomfield's Amir, Mr. E. R. Wallace's Shami, Mr. G. L. Bailey's Bhawish, Mr. G. Muir's The Monse and Mr. Btout's Valentine.

Mr. Schreiber on Valentine jumped off at che start and led till rounding the first bend when Ibn el Nur succeeded him and made the running till t of a mile from home when Hankowie went to the front and won by five lengths.
FIFTH RACE, 4 p.m. Camel Race. Value P.T. 1500 of which P.T. 300 to the 2nd and 200 to the 3rd. For Camels the property of Bedouin Arabs of Sharqia Province. Distance 3 miles. Entrance P.T. 15.
1. Mansour Bey Nasrallah's Zabet. 2. Ragheb Effendi El-Tahawy's Babbut. -
3. Khaled Effendi Fesal El-Tahawy's Abou Delua.
Eghteen started An interesting race, which the winner, a very fine animal, won easily.

SIXTH RACE, 4.30 p m. Belbeis Plate Value P.T. 1500 of which P.T. 300 to the 2nd and 200 to the 3rd For Arabs and E.C.B.'s the property cf Bedouin Arabs or Landowners of Sharqia Province. Di. tance 1 mile. Entrance P.T 75.
Owing to there being 30 entries for this race it was divided into two extra prizes of the same value being given. The result of the first race was as fol ows :

1. Mohammed Migelli Tabowie's Mismish. 2. Ragah el Tahowie's Sabrab. 3 Abou Zeid el Assa's Makhour. The Second Part. 1. Mansour Bey Nasrullah's Saluh. 2. Saad Bey Bishara's El Hiss. 3. Mansour Nasrullah's Mashkour II.
Fifteen started. Two more excellent starts but both somewhat easy wins.

SEVENTH RACE 5 p.m. Zagazig Parse. Value P.T. 3000 of which P.T 700 to the 2nd and 300 to the 3rd. For Arab horses the property of any Bedouin Arab living in Egypt. To be ridden in Arab dress by owner or one of his family. Distance 2 | miles. Entrance P.T. 150.
1. Sheik Fared Ragah's b.a.h. Mandoh. 2. Maneour Bey Nasrullah's ga.h. el Khah
tani. 3. Sheikh Radi Maftah's ch.a.h. Bukra.
Ten started. Bukra went off at a great pace and led for the first round but Mandoh thon possed him easily and won as he liked by ten lengths.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: We are glad to hear that the condition Sir William Willcocks is improving. The following telegram from Kamala was received at Cairo on Saturday:
Steadily improving, pleurisy greatly reduced very hopeful.
The following travellers left Cairo by the Train du Luxe for Upper Egypt on the 22nd inst.
Hon. Mr. Millward, Hon Mr. French, Mr. and Mrs. Hurst, Mr. Millward Masters, Mr. Koski, Mr. A. Mortkovitz, Mr. J. Maurice, Marquis Jacobi, Mr. Millaire, Mr. Foster, Mr. and Mrs. Ceeley.

Abani Pacha gave a big dinner of 50 covers at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo, on Friday evening to the officers of the Egyptian Army. The dinner was given in the new restaurant, which was beautifully decorated for this occasion. Among the guests were : Sir Reginald Wingate Pacha and Lady Wingate, Major and Mrs. Blunt, Major and Mrs. Herbert Bey, Capt, and Mrs. Rome, El Lewa and Mrs. Bernard Pacha, Miralai and Mrs. Matchett Bey, Kaim and Mrs. Timmins, Kaim and Mrs Stockwell, Sirshank Pacha, Miralai Stack Bey, Miralai Persse Bey, Lewa Henry Pacha, Miralai May Bey, Miralai Cherif Bey, Miralai Sabri Bey, Miralai Owen Boy, Miralai Palmer Boy, Miralai Tewfik Bey, Kaim Vaughan Bey, Kaim Helmy Bey, Kaim Gor don Bey, Kaim Clayton Bey, Kaim Hafez Bey Essemma, Kaim Leigh Bey, Kaimakan Amery Bey, Kaim Hutchins sn Bey, Kaim Fahmy Bey, Sagh Hayate Effendi, Bimb Orr-Ewing, Bimb Postletwaite, Bimb Bethell, Bimb Dill, Bimb Hughes, Bimb Anley, Bimb Fostor, Bimb Symes, Bimb Fuad Ef., Bimb Taw, Bimb Edgeworth, Bimb Franklin,

Clayton Gas Company of Egypt and the Sudan
(Incorporated under the Companies Acts 1862 to 1900).
DIVIDED INTO
50,000 Ordinary Shares of Lstg., 1 eacti and 10,000 Founders Shares of 1 Shilling each.
With power to increase the Capital by Resolutions in Qeneral Meeting.
The .profits of tho Company available for dividend in eaoh Financial Year shall be applicable as follows :—
Firstly .—In carrying 5 per cent, thereof to reserve.
Secondly In paying a dividend at the rate of 6 per cent, per annum to the holders of the Ordinary Shares in the Capital of the Company on the amounts paid or credited, as paid up thereon.

Thirdly :—Out of the residue of the said profits there shall be paid to the Directors an amount equal to 5 per cent, thereof and the balance shall belong as to one half thereof to the holders of the Ordin ry Shares and as to the other half thereof to the holders of the Founders Shares.

On a'distribution of the assets on the Liquidation of the Company the assets remaining after payment of the liabilities shall lie applied first in repaying the Capital paid or credited as paid up oh .the Ordinary Shares and thereafter shall be divided as to one half among the holders of the Ordinary Shares and as to the other half among the holders of the Founders Shares.
Issue of 15,030 Ordinary Scares of £ 1 each at par for Public Subscription.

Founders Shares of 1/- each will be offered for Subscription to persons who have applied for and had allotted to them Ordinary Shares in the proportion of One Founders Sliare for every ten Ordinary Shares.
The balanoe of Ordinary and Founders* Shares will be dealt with
In manner hereinafter mentioned.
No application for less than ten Ordinary Shares will be considered :
The following payments shall be made on the Ordinary Shares :—
10- per Share on Application 10, - per 8hare on Allotment
PROSPECTUS
The Company has been formed to acquire the sole rights for Egypt and the Sudan of the Clayton Process—tho several uses of which may be briefly described : —

1. (a) For Prevtaiting and extinguishing fire on board ship by rapidly generating "Clayton Gas" and forcing it under pressure into the hold or compartment to be protected, (b) and reducing the temperature of the hold or compartment in which a fire has been extinguished by circulating the gas-laden atmosphere through the cooler, (c) and by the same process reducing the temperature caused by the heating of any cargo.

2 For Fumigating and Ditirtfecfing, by charging any compartment with "Clayton Gas" of sufficient strength to be germicidal. It has. been proved that this Gas has no injurious effect on any dry material, and the baccili of plague, cholera, yellow fever, diphtheria, and typhoid are among those that have been destroyed in actual fumigations by-this system. "Clayton Gafc" also sterilizes the infection of smallpox.

3 For Pretentinq heating of Cerrals, either in warehouses or shipa'holds, by applying a sufficient strength of "Glayton Gas" to sterilize the ferment germ, without affecting the germinating properties of the grain.
4 For Ex ter in inatinq rats, insects and all rermin, such as cockroaches, bugs, fleas,

anta, weevil, etc., that infest ships warehouses and stores Ruts so destroyed come out of their holes in search of air as soon as the pungent gas reaches them, and can therefore be collected und diapoeed of without difficulty, the rink of leaving dead vormin toputrify undiscovered being thereby avoided. "Clayton Gas" destroys not only rats and vermin, but the parasites on them, and also sterilizes the eggs of insects. >

With.regard to its use for Fumigation, Prevention of and extinguishing fire on-Vessels, it is worthy of note that the system lias been adopted by the Norddeutscher Lloyd, The Hem- burg-America Line, The Union Steam Ship Co. of New Zealand, the Pacific Mail S.S Co. New*York, the Adam S.S. Co. Ltd Aberdeen. The Cie Sud American de Vapores, Valparaiso, the Pacific 8team Navigation Co., Liverpool, The British India Steam Navigation Company, The-Nippon Yusen Kaisha Co, fokio, and many other shipping Lines too numerouvto mention in this prospectus.

The importance of the Clayton system is recognised by the leading Insurance Companies and Under-Writers, who discriminate in favour of vessels equipped with it, and, in nunie>ous instances, accept risks at a reduction of premium provided the Clayton Appaiatus is installed

Fumigat an and disinfection.—Dr. Calmette, Director of the Pasteur Institute at Lille, recommends the general adoption of the Clayton System at all QunrantineStations with a view to the amelioration of existing Quarantine regulations and as an effective means of preventing the introduction of infectious diseases.

Its adoption by the French Colonial Service, the Crown Agents for the Colonies, the Governments of South Africa, Chili, P«5ru, Ecuador, etc., affords sufficient evidence of the value of .the system. Its value for the disinfection of Hospitals, Stables, etc , has also been most successfully proved to the satisfaction of many of the leading European Doctors With regard to Stables, at the Stud Farm of Val d'Etifer an epidemic of malignant glanders was completely stamped out, and the system has been adopted at the Stud Farm of Chantilly,Jardy (M. Edmond Blanc), by the Due deGiamont, — in several large cab yards of Paris h—notably that of Messrs. Radlaner where an attack of contagious pneumonia was entirely stamped out

For the prevention of the heating of cereals and the extermination of rats, all vermin and injects, so numerous are tht^mple proofs of the complete efficiency of the Clayton system that spare in this prospectus does not permit of the publication in it of the many testimonials from Expert Authorities, but they may be inspectid at the Company's Office at any time.
It is difficult tc mentic-n a country where a larger scope exists for the exploitation of the Clayton Gas System than in,Egypt' and the Sudan
The qualification of each Director is the holding of Shares or Stock of the Company of the nominal value of £200.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.
